history.content:
Since you're mostly interested in employment opportunities, as far as I know, it might be difficult to find a job as a software engineer right out of college without a CS degree. But later down the road it becomes experience >>> education "specs," so it's not like it's "No CS Degree, No CS Job." It just might be harder to get your foot through the door. I wouldn't look at it in terms of "will I get the minor or not," but rather "will I get the necessary CS knowledge or not."

Nevertheless, 61C is something you NEED to take if you're serious about working as a software engineer. If you got A's in 61A/B, then clearly you know your shit and 61C shouldn't be a roadblock for you as long as you put in the work. The thing about CS 70 is that it's not really a CS class in the traditional sense. There is 0 coding involved, and it's mostly a math/stat class (hence why it's called Discrete Math & Probability Theory). If you have a strong mathematical background, 70 should be quite manageable as well. So taking 61C and 70 over the summer together should be doable if you manage your time well and not get distracted. With these being said, I don't think you really have a choice in taking 61C; it's something you have to take to be competitive as a software engineer (in my opinion of course). 

If timing becomes an issue, there's always the option to take an extra semester to give yourself more breathing room and more opportunities to take classes (but you need to have taken less than 130 units when Fall 2017 ends; you can deduct AP credits from this total 130 unit ceiling. more info on https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/planning/enrolling/unit-ceiling). No employer is going to care if you took longer to graduate (personally heard this from many people I've connected with, including a bank executive and a startup founder), but understandably taking an extra semester can be expensive, especially if you're non-CA resident. 

When it comes to upper div's, you should really take CS 170 for interviews and a MUCH stronger knowledge in programming. I've also heard from previous CS majors that 186, 162, and 168 are also very useful in industry, but 170 and 162 is very workload-intensive, so you'd have to strategize your classes well. For your bolded question, well, it all comes down to how serious you are about software engineering. Is it something you're doing simply because it has a lot of job prospects and it's the "next big thing" in careers, or does developing programs truly make you happy and stimulate you intellectually? Whether or not it's "worth it" would depend on the answer to that question.

These are just my 2 cents. Good luck with your remaining semester(s) and I hope you find success as a software engineer!

children.subject: Thanks for the response. That was incredibly constructive and just the advice I needed. CS has been among a small set of subjects I really enjoyed learning. Breaking down 70 & 61C as math and traditional CS classes definitely makes the pairing seem more manageable. Looks like I'm committing to a fun summer.

history.content:
Have you seen this page? Look at the box that says "CS Minors: Where are they now?" Many minors are software engineers/data scientists/in prestigious PhD programs in EECS. 

GL!

I'm trying to compare how worthwhile it would be for me to officially complete the CS minor as opposed to tacking on a few more CS classes. Rephrased: how would this affect my job search experience as a prospective software engineer?

Where I'm at:

  • Expected graduation: Fall 2017
  • Completed MCB Major requirements
  • Finished CS61A&B (A's in both classes) this past school year

I took 61A and enjoyed the class enough that I couldn't see myself further pursuing research science or medicine and decided to turn convert my remaining time at Berkeley into a CS bootcamp. I'm enrolled in both 61C & 70 this summer and I'm planning on taking 3 upper divs in the fall (169, 170, +1). I've received a lot of feedback that software engineering does not necessarily require knowledge of machine language & architecture, but obviously the best engineers have a great understanding of everything between hardware & software. So I'm on the fence as to whether or not I should take 61C concurrently with 70 in the summer, since the workloads would be more intense during a compressed semester (comes out to 2 labs, 1 project, 1 homework per week outside of accelerated lecture & discussion pace). No 61C, no minor - so I'm wondering how that will impact my employment opportunities

TL;DR:

  • Graduating soon
  • Turning remaining time into CS bootcamp (originally MCB major)
  • Deciding factor of securing the minor is taking 61C concurrently with 70 during the summer
  • Will sacrificing a little bit of my sanity this summer be worth it down the road?
history.subject: Value of the CS Minor
